title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [6] february [1870]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [6] February [1870]
text: Feb 1Februarydear walti received your letter yesterday and the order and am very much obliged to you indeed the paper came totoo i was amused to read the account of the ball and the prince sprince's manoversmaneuvers i should think by the account he behaved with great propriety and very good taste in his dress and his behavior) well walt Georgey aintain't home yet i haventhaven't heard a word from him since he went away the 1 of the month i think he might just write a line to me i expected he would be home last saturdaySaturday but he didentdidn't come so i suppose he will be here this saturSaturdayi haveenthaven't had no word from Jeffie nor martha since i wrote to you last week i sent a letter to Jeff yesterday neither have i had any word from han but that i dontdon't think so strange of as she dontdon't write more than once or twice in the year) helen price has been here and I gave her the paper with your peicepiece in she was much pleased with it very much indeed she wished me to say to you she was obliged to you and received it as a christmas present she is working in that place i spoke about mr stitson i beleivebelieve his name is a lawyer of pattenspatents she gets from to daytoday 8 dollars a week she has had 6 she is glad she can earn something she has given what she has earned to her mother but what she now gets she will get a nice black silk) i gessguess mrs price is like many others short of funds sometime walter my son this is the only envelopei shall go down to the post office to day if it aintain't sliperyslippery Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [6] February [1870]
